stem: A 33-year-old client (35 weeks gestation) with known preeclampsia reports severe epigastric pain and nausea. Based on the documentation in the Critical OB Labs & Hepatic Status tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute deterioration in a preeclamptic client.
Background: G2P1. Admitted for monitoring of BP 152/94.
Assessment: Client looks jaundice. Reports RUQ (Right Upper Quadrant) pain that is worsening.
Recommendation: Immediate delivery and stabilization of clotting factors.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 172/114, HR 102, RR 22, SpO2 95% on RA. Petechiae noted on arms.

actionOptions.text: Prepare for emergent delivery of the fetus
Initiate a transfusion of platelets as prescribed
Apply heat packs to the epigastric region for pain relief
Wait for 24 hours to observe if the liver enzymes stabilize

parameterOptions.text: Platelet count and signs of bleeding/DIC
Hepatic enzyme levels (AST/ALT) and clinical RUQ pain

rationale.correct: This is HELLP Syndrome (c1), a severe variant of preeclampsia. The acronym stands for Hemolysis (low Hgb/High Bilirubin), Elevated Liver enzymes (AST/ALT), and Low Platelets. The presence of epigastric pain and petechiae are classic symptoms. The only 'cure' is delivery (a1), and the low platelets put her at high risk for hemorrhage, requiring product support (a2). Key parameters include tracking the clotting ability (p1) and liver failure progression (p2).
clinicalPearls: HELLP can occur even if the blood pressure is not 'severely' high.
Right upper quadrant (RUQ) or Epigastric pain is caused by the liver being stretched under its capsule (Glisson's capsule).
DIC (Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation) is the most dangerous complication of HELLP.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking epigastric pain is just 'heartburn' from the growing uterus.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: In a preeclamptic patient, epigastric pain is a RED FLAG for HELLP or impending seizure. It must be investigated with labs immediately.

mnemonic.title: HELLP
mnemonic.expansion: H-Hemolysis. EL-Elevated Liver Enzymes. LP-Low Platelets.
